abstract.p: Bruce Bartlett letter on May 29 article says online sources cited in footnotes are inaccessible to those without Internet access, can disappear or be hard to locate

block.p: Re ''The Book's in Print, but Its Bibliography Lives in Cyberspace'' (front page, May 29):

It is increasingly common for writers to footnote or refer to material that exists only online. The problem with this, aside from inaccessibility for those without Internet access, is that Web pages often come and go. Sometimes the material just disappears, sometimes the Web site address changes without notice, and sometimes a small error in the address makes it impossible to find the exact reference. Moreover, there is no generally agreed-upon method for citing online material.
Re ''The Book's in Print, but Its Bibliography Lives in Cyberspace'' (front page, May 29):

It is increasingly common for writers to footnote or refer to material that exists only online. The problem with this, aside from inaccessibility for those without Internet access, is that Web pages often come and go. Sometimes the material just disappears, sometimes the Web site address changes without notice, and sometimes a small error in the address makes it impossible to find the exact reference. Moreover, there is no generally agreed-upon method for citing online material.
Scholars should quickly develop some guidelines for citing and preserving research material in this medium, lest it become a step backward rather than a step forward in the pursuit of knowledge.
BRUCE BARTLETT Great Falls, Va., May 29, 2000
The writer is a senior fellow at the National Center for Policy Analysis.
